threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
/vrpg/ is a place to discuss all types of role-playing video games, including single-player, multi-player, and massively multi-player, turn-based and real-time action, western-style and JRPG.

Does this mean RPGs are banned on other video game boards? No! /vrpg/ is just a separate board specifically focused on RPGs where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vrpg/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/.

Medicine stick and brush gun are your fuck you damage dealers. Only downside is some rare rifle ammo.

Ranger Seqoia is the nice accurate damgae dealing revolver. But don't sleep on the hunting revolver, as it has a scope which the Ranger does not!

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: What is the correct mindset to enjoy DRPGs?
threads.com:
I've tried playing some DRPGs and there's a lot of things I like about them:
>party management
>free character creation, allowing for a multitude of approaches
>first person exploration is usually immersive
>I like drawing maps and making my own notes

Even though I like all these things, there's one thing that always filters me in these games: the combat. No matter how much I try, it seems that all the DRPGs really on two types of battles: the ones where you mash attack until the enemy is dead without worrying about anything and the ones where you try to mash attack to win but the enemy completely destroys your whole party with just one attack. This second option usually becomes a RNG fest, because while the enemy always has this attack that wipes your party, it can use it on turn 1, turn 10 or never use it, so it all comes down to luck.
So, what you do to enjoy this? Do you just accept that combat is shit and decide to have a good time with the remaining characteristics of the game?

By Chapter 8, you're rounding up the band to help out and you can save Lucas and co., it would make the ending a lot cooler and you really feel like you brought the people of the islands together.

>>2854786
My biggest complaints with Nocturne:
- Saving is SLOW. We're talking like 7-10 seconds of unskippable animation just to save your progress, not including another 10 seconds of loading time to enter and exit the save room.
- There's no reverse fusion so you better have a fusion calculator handy if you want to target specific demons with specific skills
- Random encounters with unreasonable encounter rates
- You are kinda forced into a strength build late game since magic stat for some reason falls off hard as your level gets higher. Also luck is virtually useless. This is not mentioned anywhere in the game
- Based on my experience it is super easy to get instagibbed by some random encounter (compared to SMT V)
- The magatama system is unforgiving. SMT V allows you to learn and forget a demon's skill as much as you want. In Nocturne you learn skills by equipping a magatama and leveling up. You only get that opportunity once, so switching builds is basically an irreversible process.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
All three of the endings are both good and bad.

>Illuminati
Well, it's more of the same. The world will go on as it already does. There will be nations and corporations benefitting from the toil of the underclasses. But they won't try to exterminate them or oppress them, since that's not entirely profitable. So we'll end up in essentially today's world, but with more tech.

>Villages
I think what was missed is that the technology that people have won't go away. It's that the global communication protocols will go down. So it's less of "everyone is a tribal savage with spears and rocks" and more like "cities are cut off from each other and there won't be global travel for a couple of years." So basically, a bunch of people die and there's societal collapse because of the full supply chain collapse, but it also gives time for new entities and alliances to form, so that when the system restarts, people are more likely to form bonds based on mutualism.

>Helios
Well, the dude turned moral. He didn't want to oppress the world with Bob Page. He sought out Denton because he knew he was morally flawed and couldn't be trusted to make moral decisions - just utilitarian ones. People in China were happy because utilitarianism was better than what they had, but other places would benefit from a more humanized perspective. But of course, will the merger actually work? Will the entity that arises still be moral? Ehhhh. Big question there.

threads.com: this isn't about deus ex vs. fallout, just the inventory system. i like that with a grid you can see everything at once instead of scrolling through a list and having 5 different lists, but only having 30 different spaces means you can't carry a large variety of items. with a list, there can be lots of different things with very small weights, like ammo. each round has a low weight but it adds up realistically, so you can decide if you want to carry a variety of calibers or just a ton of ammo for one gun you like. in deus ex, you have absolute ammo limits like 150 10mm rounds. i know human revolution's grid has smaller spaces and more of them, which means ammo can be kept in the main inventory, but in that when you have a lot of ammo of one type it clutters your grid because it only stacks up to 50 rounds in a box so you'll have ten boxes of the same thing all over your inventory, so i like the deus ex 1 grid more. STALKER is a weird case because it's limited by weight but displays things on a grid with infinite spaces. i never liked that because you still carry a lot of different items like artifacts, ammo types, and every duplicate weapon still appears in a new space instead of ak-74 (x3) or something. so all that combined with items having images and everything being in one category means your inventory can be so visually cluttered you have to scroll way down to find something even if you're way under the weight limit. i don't hate it, it's just a little weird. it probably comes down to the complexity of the game. like i was saying, lists can do small objects and an infinite variety of things but for an action game the grid being simpler and faster to look through is better.

>>2854068

Valheim handles it the best I've ever seen.
>veg comes from your own garden that you have to hoe and spacer the planting rows, and pull up satisfying big onion and beet models a la super mario 2
>you get meat from slaughtering in the wild or your own domesticated animals you captured and tamed, and you have to keep crops going to feed them also
>subcomponents like sausage skin from zombie intestines, or blood item from swamp leeches, or frozen eyeballs from winter wyverns to make eye scream
>also honey harvesting from beehives
>you can ferment with the honey which is the basis for all magic potions (meads)
>cooking upgrades are rewards from boss killing like all crafting or unlocking a new vegetable with seeds from a new biome
>there are no penalty mechanics for not eating but the actual buffs themselves are almost required to fight effectively (as your stats are super gimp without), but with your choice of how to layer a few different buff slots on at once depending on what kind of fighting style you like. Easier to make food/eating light with cheap ingredients gets you by for easy missions or maybe just farming around the base but you want to break out the deluxe stuff for boss fights
>literal comfy level based on your home environment you cook in, big hearthy fires and things like spice racks or ornaments, rugs, add to it which gives you more bonuses while doing the cooking itself

All of it makes it fun to farm and stock a big pantry so you feel well equipped and can help your friends load up the wagons and longships for long mining or boss fight trips into the wilds.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Daggerfall requires a lot of effort on the player to enjoy. A lot of suspension of disbelief. But if you allow yourself to be fooled, it is actually a very fun game. Even though every quest and city is procedurally generated, after you've been playing for a while you kind of allow the illusion that every location is unique to grow on you. You get a sense of scale and realism that no other RPG offers.

I remember Zaric saying that every region in Daggerfall felt unique to him. I thought this was nonsense. How could a region feel unique when it uses the exact same generation algorithm as every other generic region in the game? I didn't understand this until I properly played Daggerfall and gave it a chance rather than dismissing it as procedurally generated garbage like I had done before. For example, over time you remember certain town layouts, you find a city with all the right services that your character requires in the one place, or you grow fond of a city that you've done a lot of quests in. And after a while of helping people out you see your reputation in a region has grown, it feels good that your actions in this world actually mean something.

Daggerfall definitely has something that no other RPG I've played has. A sense of immersion that you really are just an itinerant adventurer living in a fantasy world. Even though it's from 1996 it feels surprisingly modern in the amount of freedom it gives you.

Of course, the Unity version and shit ton of mods help a lot too. There are a lot of quest and world overhaul mods so the game doesn't feel so samey all the time.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Let us compare Nocturne "the best JRPG game ever made" to what most people say is the best RPG ever made: Deus Ex.

Nocturne requires you to fight very single damn thing including the shitty bosses. Deus Ex doesn't require any violence, allowing you to play the game at your own pace.

Deus Ex gives you freedom of choice, ranging from story choices to how you navigate levels. Nocturne gives you the former, but not the latter since you have to follow a predetermined path.

Expanding on this, Deus Ex also has multiple solutions to every problem, meaning that no two playthroughs are the same. Nocturne may allow for more freedom than most JRPGs (talking to demons), but it still has the potential to be as linear as it's contemporaries.

Let's look at obtaining the pass from the collector in the sewers just before the Matador fight for example. In order to obtain the pass you need so the guard at the gate will let you through, you need to get it from the collector. He'll give you it if you help him find a 1 Yen bill. Obtaining this bill requires you to break into the back room of a bar and steal it.

The problem with this is that this is the only method to get past the gate. I'm the fucking Demi-Fiend, so why can't I just beat the shit out of the gate guard or collector so I can get what I want? Why can't I buy the one yen bill from the bar owner for a reasonable price? Why can't I find a fake bill to give the collector?

And don't forget that Nocturne starts with an hour of cutscenes and story interactions while Deus Ex immediately hands the player control from the start of the game and never takes it away. (Despite the fact that Nocturne stops focusing on the story when you hit the vortex world, making the first hour of the game redundant.)

Deus Ex, and most other RPGs, would let you do these things because an RPG is about player expression. Nocturne's single approach however, is just this: linear, contrived bullshit

Andromeda's failure was taking us so completely away from the setting. threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
What exactly is the good part of this game? I was told it was supposed to be good, but I'm not sure I've ever felt more insulted by a game. It's designed so poorly in so many ways.

- Hardly any control over party members
- Combat is mostly just mashing the attack button, whether you are using links or not
- Battles with random mobs are never interesting. Too easy and just there to be in the way
- Only battles with any difficulty are forced solo battles which make the game even more barebones, and even those are scarce
- Feels like 1/3 of the "bosses" are forced losses where you randomly get one-shotted by volty
- Most of the 177 characters are unappealing peasants no one would ever want to play as, reducing the potential depth of the better ones (like Chrono Cross, but worse)
- To customize your party you have to do inane tasks wandering around town for the first 20 hours until you figure out how to get the one you want, if you even manage it. This is most of the game's "gameplay"
- The character you like may be level 5 when recruited 20 hours into the game, or be irredeemably bad in another way
- You can't even use the characters you like in most story battles or even any battles if you pick the wrong path, completely missing the point of having party customization
- Irredeemable bland dungeons with literal corridors that lead to nothing
- No escape rope or warp without running to a pig statue
- Stupid time system that meshes poorly with surprise story triggers
- Item limit with no storage except the jukebox

This doesn't even get into the story which is a dumpster fire in its own way. The only thing that's OK is the music, and even that has an asterisk, because it's never been more obvious that the programmer placed the music and not the composer. The audio balance is poor, with the BGM drowning out the VA. The choice of where to place music also sometimes feels unfitting, for example in cutscenes or a few dungeons (also awkward use of sitcom SFX in cutscenes.)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2853976
>Does anyone have any more information on that?
It was one of Karpyshyn's earlier drafts for ME3 in which it explained that the Reapers were created to specifically slow down the spread of dark energy by wiping out advanced species every 50000 years before they reached the point of using too much Mass Effect technology, or else there'd be a macroscale cataclysm which would lead up to a Big Crunch scenario and end the universe. Haestrom's sun in ME2 (a young star which quickly entered its red giant phase) was hinting towards this, and supposedly, the geth were investigating it & were trying to formulate a solution of their own to counteract the threat of runaway dark energy. The ending originally involved Shepard conversing with Harbinger and being given two choices: either destroy the Reapers & let everyone find their own eventual solution to the dark energy threat, or surrender to the Reapers & allow humanity to be harvested in exchange for letting the other galactic races survive, with the latter choice explaining how humans had the greatest genetic potential to produce extraordinarily powerful Reapers that could be capable of resolving the threat of unstable dark energy for the foreseeable future (which would've revealed why the Reapers focused on exclusively processing a Human Reaper in ME2, as the deleted audio lines of Harbinger hinted at).
Now, Karpyshyn himself has neither denied nor supported this, stating another ending involving some "Reaper Queen" was in the works, but that was likely a secondary draft in the midst of the development hell ME3 went through before release. Regardless, he was pushed out by Mac Walters in favor of the "Synthetics vs. Organics" asspull instead. That's it.

>>2851387
I understand a lot of the points, and agree with some, less with others, but not enough to articulate now. I'll say my piece though.

You should remember that emulation is only a tool. You don't have to utilize it every time you play a game. Sometimes you will enjoy relaxing and unwinding, listening to the music, the sound effects, and watching the animations. That is of course provided they are done well.

If it's a grindy game and you want to speed up that process, then take the tool out of your bag or box and make use of it for a time, but then go back to playing the game.

If the emulator you use can speed up without janking the music and sound, then that's even better for grinding. I know you can always have things muted, or an external playlist, but that breaks some of the immersion, and then you're basically just playing something as dumb as cookie clicker or leaf blowing simulator.

Now Leaf Klicker and Cookie Blower... those we need to talk about.

>Fultheim is a former Blade (if you check his items, the books in his room and ask the innkeeper about him)
>You can use a calming spell on Boethia's Champion to engage in dialog with him rather than killing him, and it turns out he wanted to turn his back on violence/the daedra
>If you steal the soul gem in Arondil's lair without him noticing, his servant-ghost turns on him
>You can give the Jagged Crown to the rival faction to the one you've joined up with, which allows you to defect
>Lost Prospect, an otherwise abandoned, empty mine has a whole little story (not marked) with a journal detailing how the owner gradually loses hope as they only turn up small quantities of quicksilver and feels his partner has run off and abandoned him. His partner, if you check a hidden chamber behind the waterfall, didn't die and was instead crushed by a collapsing tunnel (that leads into a chamber full of gold)

What are your favorite little details from Skyrim, /vrpg/?
